evaluatedLibraries.name: 3D Slicer
evaluatedLibraries.description: 3D Slicer is a free, open-source software package developed by the Surgical Planning Laboratory at the Harvard Medical School. It is primarily used for 3D visualization and analysis of medical images, making it particularly useful in neuroimaging studies. It supports a wide array of functionalities including image segmentation, registration, and 3D visualization.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Amira
evaluatedLibraries.description: Developed by Thermo Fisher Scientific, Amira is a 3D visualization and analysis software. It specializes in handling complex 3D models and has extensive applications in neuroscience for visualizing and analyzing brain structures.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Analysis of Functional NeuroImages (AFNI)
evaluatedLibraries.description: AFNI is a software suite developed by the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) to analyze and visualize functional MRI data. It is particularly suitable for cognitive neuroscience research.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Analyze
evaluatedLibraries.description: Created by the Biomedical Imaging Resource (BIR) at Mayo Clinic, Analyze is a software application used for visualization and analysis in biomedical imaging, including neuroimaging.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Brain Image Analysis Package
evaluatedLibraries.description: This software package, developed by a team of neuroscientists at Johns Hopkins University, focuses on detailed analysis of brain images. It uses advanced algorithms for image processing, making it suitable for research that requires high precision.

evaluatedLibraries.name: CamBA
evaluatedLibraries.description: CamBA is a proprietary neuroimaging software developed by a team at the University of Cambridge. It uses advanced machine learning algorithms to analyze brain activation patterns and is particularly suited for research into cognitive processes.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Caret
evaluatedLibraries.description: Developed by the Van Essen Lab at Washington University in St. Louis, Caret software is widely used for surface-based data analysis in neuroscience. It is particularly effective in mapping cortical structures and visualizing brain connectivity data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: CONN
evaluatedLibraries.description: CONN is a functional connectivity toolbox developed under a joint collaboration of MIT, Harvard, and Massachusetts General Hospital. It is tailored for dynamic connectivity analysis in brain imaging studies.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Diffusion Imaging in Python (DIPY)
evaluatedLibraries.description: DIPY is an open-source project driven by a community of researchers passionate about diffusion MRI. It is particularly known for its strong emphasis on reproducibility and best practices in software development.

evaluatedLibraries.name: DL+DiReCT
evaluatedLibraries.description: DL+DiReCT is a cutting-edge neuroimaging software developed by a private laboratory in Silicon Valley. It uses deep learning algorithms to analyze and interpret neuroimaging data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: EEGLAB
evaluatedLibraries.description: EEGLAB is a popular open-source MATLAB toolbox for processing continuous and event-related EEG data. Developed at the University of California, San Diego, it is particularly known for its user-friendly GUI and wide range of statistical analysis options.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FMRIB Software Library (FSL)
evaluatedLibraries.description: The FMRIB Software Library, more commonly known as FSL, is a comprehensive library of analysis tools for FMRI, MRI and DTI brain imaging data. It was developed by the Oxford Centre for Functional MRI of the Brain (FMRIB).

evaluatedLibraries.name: FreeSurfer
evaluatedLibraries.description: FreeSurfer is a software package developed by the Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging at Massachusetts General Hospital. It is designed for the analysis and visualization of structural and functional neuroimaging data from cross-sectional and longitudinal studies.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Imaris for Neuroscientists
evaluatedLibraries.description: Imaris for Neuroscientists is a powerful visualization and analysis software designed specifically for neuroscientists. Developed by Bitplane, it provides a comprehensive solution for the visualization and analysis of 3D and 4D microscopy datasets.

evaluatedLibraries.name: ISAS
evaluatedLibraries.description: ISAS (Ictal-Interictal SPECT Analysis by SPM) is a unique software developed by a team at John Hopkins University. It specializes in the analysis of ictal and interictal states in epilepsy research.

evaluatedLibraries.name: LONI Pipeline
evaluatedLibraries.description: LONI Pipeline, developed by the Laboratory of Neuro Imaging at the University of Southern California, provides a graphical environment for construction, validation and execution of advanced computational protocols. This tool is particularly useful for facilitating the use of heterogeneous computational resources and enables distributed computing.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Mango
evaluatedLibraries.description: Mango, short for Multi-image Analysis GUI, is a viewer for medical research images. Developed at the Research Imaging Institute of the University of Texas Health Science Center, it supports a wide range of image formats and offers capabilities for visualizing and analyzing 3D and 4D data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: NITRC
evaluatedLibraries.description: NITRC, or the Neuroimaging Informatics Tools and Resources Clearinghouse, is a resource developed under an NIH grant. It aims to provide a platform for researchers to share, find, and use neuroimaging resources, promoting collaboration and transparency in the field.

evaluatedLibraries.name: NeuroKit
evaluatedLibraries.description: NeuroKit is a Python open-source toolbox for physiological signal processing. It was developed by a team of researchers at Stanford University, and is used extensively in neuroscience research for the analysis of signals such as EEG, ECG, and EMG.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Neurophysiological Biomarker Toolbox
evaluatedLibraries.description: The Neurophysiological Biomarker Toolbox is a novel software library, developed by a team at the University of Michigan. It is designed to identify biomarkers in neurophysiological data, particularly in the field of mental health research.

evaluatedLibraries.name: PyNets
evaluatedLibraries.description: PyNets is an open-source workflow for structural and functional connectome ensemble learning. It was developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and has been adopted by neuroscience researchers worldwide.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Seed-based d mapping
evaluatedLibraries.description: Seed-based d mapping (previously signed differential mapping) is a method for conducting meta-analyses of voxel-based neuroimaging studies. This tool was developed under a government grant from the National Institute of Health.

evaluatedLibraries.name: The Spinal Cord Toolbox
evaluatedLibraries.description: The Spinal Cord Toolbox is the first comprehensive and open-source software for processing MR images of the spinal cord. It was developed by a consortium of researchers from institutions around the globe.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Statistical parametric mapping (SPM)
evaluatedLibraries.description: Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM) is a software package designed for the analysis of brain imaging data sequences. The SPM software is a suite of MATLAB functions and subroutines with some externally compiled C routines. SPM was written to organize and interpret our functional neuroimaging data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: BrainIAK
evaluatedLibraries.description: BrainIAK, a software library developed by the Princeton Neuroscience Institute, is a high-performance computing toolbox for fMRI data. The library is designed to utilize high-performance computing resources efficiently, making it well-suited for large-scale fMRI studies.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Nilearn
evaluatedLibraries.description: Nilearn is a software library developed by a team at the French National Institute for Research in Computer Science and Automation. It uses machine learning algorithms to analyze functional MRI data, and is particularly well-regarded for its user-friendly API and detailed documentation.

evaluatedLibraries.name: fitlins
evaluatedLibraries.description: Fitlins, developed by the team at the Montreal Neurological Institute, is a software library that fits generalized linear models to fMRI data. Fitlins relies heavily on the Brain Imaging Data Structure standard, showcasing its commitment to open standards and reproducibility.

evaluatedLibraries.name: glmsingle
evaluatedLibraries.description: Glmsingle, a tool implemented in both Matlab and Python, was developed at the University of Cambridge. It focuses on the estimation of single-trial responses and has been particularly useful in cognitive neuroscience research.

evaluatedLibraries.name: DIPY
evaluatedLibraries.description: DIPY, or Diffusion Imaging in Python, is a software library for the analysis of diffusion MRI data. It was developed by a group of researchers at the University of Sheffield and has been instrumental in the study of brain white matter.

evaluatedLibraries.name: DMIPY
evaluatedLibraries.description: Building upon DIPY, DMIPY is a specialized tool for modeling the microstructure of brain white matter tissue. It was developed under a government grant at the Max Planck Institute for Human Cognitive and Brain Sciences.

evaluatedLibraries.name: pyAFQ
evaluatedLibraries.description: PyAFQ, or Automated Fiber Quantification in Python, is a tool that focuses on delineating major white matter tracts. Created by the researchers at the University of California, San Francisco, it's a powerful tool for understanding brain connectivity.

evaluatedLibraries.name: TractSeg
evaluatedLibraries.description: TractSeg is a fast and accurate tool for the automatic segmentation of white matter tracts from diffusion MRI data. Developed at the University of Oxford, it has become a standard tool in many neuroimaging labs.

evaluatedLibraries.name: NDMG
evaluatedLibraries.description: NDMG, or NeuroData's MRI Graphs, is a tool that focuses on quantifying the connectivity matrix of the brain based on dMRI data. It's a joint project of researchers from Johns Hopkins University and the National Institute of Mental Health.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Medical Imaging Toolkit for Diffusion
evaluatedLibraries.description: The Medical Imaging Toolkit for Diffusion is a widely-used software library for analysis of dMRI. Developed by a team at the University of Pennsylvania, it offers a comprehensive suite of tools for processing and analyzing diffusion MRI data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: ANTs
evaluatedLibraries.description: The Advanced Normalization Tools (ANTs) software library, developed by the University of Pennsylvania, implements a variety of algorithms for structural MRI data, such as image registration and image segmentation. Its wide array of capabilities have made it a staple in neuroimaging research.

evaluatedLibraries.name: antspy
evaluatedLibraries.description: Antspy is the Python interface for the ANTs library, developed to make the powerful tools of ANTs more accessible to the broader Python-based data science community. It was created through a collaborative effort between the University of Pennsylvania and the Broad Institute.

evaluatedLibraries.name: MNE
evaluatedLibraries.description: The MNE software library, in development since 2011, focuses on electrophysiology data analysis. Originating from the Athinoula A. Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging, it offers algorithms that are common across different types of data, including MEG, EEG, and ECoG.

evaluatedLibraries.name: NiPy
evaluatedLibraries.description: NiPy, or Neuroimaging in Python, is a collection of Python libraries and tools for neuroimaging data analysis. Developed by a collaborative team from Stanford University and the University of California, Berkeley, it's known for its ease of use and flexibility.

evaluatedLibraries.name: SCHMRIB Software Library (SCHSL)
evaluatedLibraries.description: The SCHMRIB Software Library, or SCHSL, is a comprehensive library of analysis tools for functional, structural and diffusion MRI brain imaging data. Developed by the Schmoxford University SCHMRIB Centre, it has been widely adopted in the neuroimaging community.

evaluatedLibraries.name: Analysis of Dysfunctional NeuroImages (ADNI)
evaluatedLibraries.description: ADNI, or Analysis of Dysfunctional NeuroImages, is a set of software libraries developed at the National Institutes of Health. It offers a broad range of tools for processing and analyzing functional MRI data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: MRTRIX
evaluatedLibraries.description: MRTRIX, developed by the Florey Institute of Neuroscience and Mental Health, is a software library for the processing, analysis and visualization of diffusion MRI datasets. Its robust algorithms and visualization tools make it a favorite in the neuroimaging community.

evaluatedLibraries.name: PaidSurfer
evaluatedLibraries.description: PaidSurfer, a software suite developed at the Athinoula A. Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging, is a set of tools for the analysis and visualization of structural and functional brain imaging data. Its powerful surface-based processing capabilities have set the standard in the field.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FEAT
evaluatedLibraries.description: FEAT, or FMRI Expert Analysis Tool, is part of the FMRIB Software Library developed at Oxford University. It specializes in the statistical analysis and visualization of functional MRI data, with a particular focus on time-series data.

evaluatedLibraries.name: MELODIC
evaluatedLibraries.description: MELODIC, developed by the Oxford University FMRIB Centre, is a tool for performing multivariate exploratory linear optimized decomposition into independent components of fMRI data. It has been pivotal in advancing our understanding of functional connectivity.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FABBER
evaluatedLibraries.description: FABBER is an advanced Bayesian model fitting tool included in the FMRIB Software Library. Developed by the Oxford University FMRIB Centre, it is used to model time series data, particularly in the context of pharmacological studies.

evaluatedLibraries.name: BASIL
evaluatedLibraries.description: BASIL, part of the FMRIB Software Library, is a toolset developed at Oxford University for the analysis of perfusion and arterial spin labelling data. It's a key resource in the study of cerebral blood flow.

evaluatedLibraries.name: VERBENA
evaluatedLibraries.description: VERBENA is a tool within the FMRIB Software Library, developed by Oxford University, that focuses on the analysis of brain network connectivity using eigenvector centrality mapping.

evaluatedLibraries.name: BET
evaluatedLibraries.description: Brain Extraction Tool (BET) is a part of the FMRIB Software Library from Oxford University. Its specialty lies in extracting brain and skull images from MRI scans. It utilizes robust algorithms for separating brain matter from non-brain matter, and it has been extensively used in the field of neurosurgery.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FAST
evaluatedLibraries.description: FAST, FMRIB's Automated Segmentation Tool, is a part of the FMRIB Software Library. It was developed by the Oxford University FMRIB Centre and it is primarily used for segmenting a 3D image of the brain into different tissue types. It has proven effective for both research and clinical applications.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FIRST
evaluatedLibraries.description: FMRIB's Integrated Registration and Segmentation Tool (FIRST) is part of the FMRIB Software Library, developed at Oxford University. It's designed to provide robust and accurate segmentation of subcortical brain structures, making it an invaluable tool in studies of brain anatomy.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FLIRT
evaluatedLibraries.description: FLIRT (FMRIB's Linear Image Registration Tool) is a part of the FMRIB Software Library from Oxford University. This tool specializes in the registration of brain images, and it's widely used in both clinical and research settings to align brain images from different subjects or modalities.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FNIRT
evaluatedLibraries.description: FNIRT, or FMRIB's Non-linear Image Registration Tool, is part of the FMRIB Software Library developed at Oxford University. It excels at registering brain images using non-linear transformations, making it particularly useful in research involving populations with significant anatomical variance.

evaluatedLibraries.name: FSLVBM
evaluatedLibraries.description: FSLVBM, a part of the FMRIB Software Library developed at Oxford University, focuses on the voxel-based morphometry of brain images. It was designed to aid researchers in understanding structural changes in the brain, particularly those related to neurodegenerative diseases.

evaluatedLibraries.name: SIENA
evaluatedLibraries.description: SIENA (Structural Image Evaluation, using Normalisation, of Atrophy) is a tool from the FMRIB Software Library. Developed at Oxford University, it specializes in the assessment of brain atrophy. It has been instrumental in the study of neurodegenerative diseases.

evaluatedLibraries.name: SIENAX
evaluatedLibraries.description: SIENAX, part of the FMRIB Software Library from Oxford University, is an extension of SIENA. It provides a cross-sectional method to assess brain volume changes, making it a powerful tool for studying conditions such as multiple sclerosis.

evaluatedLibraries.name: MIST
evaluatedLibraries.description: MIST (Magnetic resonance Imaging Segmentation Tool) is a module within the FMRIB Software Library from Oxford University. MIST offers a comprehensive solution for segmenting MR images of the brain, proving especially useful in delineating brain structures in research.

evaluatedLibraries.name: BIANCA
evaluatedLibraries.description: BIANCA (Brain Intensity AbNormality Classification Algorithm) is a part of the FMRIB Software Library developed at Oxford University. It excels at identifying abnormal voxels in brain images, particularly in the context of white matter lesions.

benefits: Being able to cite the software in grant applications and publications
Reasonable degree of certainty other will be able to install and use your code
Accessibility across a range of user experience
Increasing the likelihood of your tool being used
Greater stability during development due to tests constantly checking code
A greater sense of community guidelines, attracting contributors
Extensive documentation assists users with more advanced use cases
JoSS will increase the visibility of your project

items.prompt: Landing page (e.g., GitHub README, website) provides a link to documentation and brief description of what program does
Documentation is up to date with version of software
An example of its usage is shown
Document functions intended to be used by users
Description of required input parameters for user-facing functions with reasonable description of inputs
items.clarification: "NIfTI of brain mask in MNI" vs. "An image file"
either through GitHub or external site

items.prompt: Digital Object Identifier (DOI) points to latest version
All documented installation instructions can be successfully followed
Provide / generate / point to test data
Provide instructions for users to run tests that include instructions for evaluation for correct behavior
One or more tutorial to showcase the multiple of the program's usages
Any alternative usage that is advertised is thoroughly documented
Thorough description of required and optional input parameters
A statement of supported operating systems / environments
Some form of testing suite present
Continuous integration badges in README for build status
Continuous integration badges in README for tests passing
Continuous integration badges in README for coverage

examples: expected turnaround time on pull requests

items.prompt: Journal of Open Source Software submission
Benchmarking information is provided for examples
